Material.Text: F1: Next up on the agenda is a program we are very proud of. We have available to all our employees, both part- and full-time, a matching gift program, which means that for qualified charitable organizations, we will match your donation, dollar for dollar. This effectively doubles your donation. It's a way to encourage our employees to give to causes that matter to them, as well as to help impact our community. You'll find a description of the program in your welcome packet. There you can read about what criteria each charity must meet in order to qualify for this program, before deciding which one you want to contribute to.

QuestionText.Text: According to the speaker, what is one of the benefits of the program?

AnswerSentence.Text: It increases the amount given to charity.
It helps the company look good.

It is free advertising for the company.

AnswerSentence.Text: giving money to a student to pay for school expenses
giving money to a homeless shelter
giving money to a child-sponsorship organization
giving money to an organization that helps disabled people

Material.Text: M1: As you know, we will have university studentseducation majorsworking in our classrooms beginning next week, as a part of their teaching practicum course. Today, I want to review the requirements of the program so that you're familiar with what should and shouldnt be expected of them. The first question I usually get is, "are these student teachers allowed to teach?" Since theyll be in your classrooms two days per week for the semester, I suggest that you let them observe you for the first couple weeks. As the term progresses, you can allow them to take a more active role, and by the end, you should give them the opportunity to teach a class or two themselves.

QuestionText.Text: What will happen next week?

AnswerSentence.Text: University students will start visiting a school.
University students will begin teaching class.
Some teachers will attend a training course.
Some teachers will observe each others classes.

QuestionText.Text: What suggestion does the speaker make about education majors?

AnswerSentence.Text: They should spend some time watching experienced teachers.
They should be given as much responsibility as possible.
They shouldnt be allowed to teach until they graduate.
They shouldnt be allowed in class before meeting the requirements.

QuestionText.Text: What is the purpose of the talk?

AnswerSentence.Text: to go over the details of a special program
to discuss changes to a class schedule
to announce a new program for education majors
to give lesson planning tips to teachers

Material.Text: The "gluten-free" movement recommends that people cut gluten, a protein found in grains like wheat, rye, and barley, from their diets. The vast majority of people are able to digest gluten, but for people with celiac disease, the consumption of gluten is genuinely dangerous. For these people, the rise of gluten-free awareness is both a blessing and a curse. On the positive side, because it is in the public consciousness, there are many more food choices available to them. On the negative side, because there are so many people who claim to be gluten intolerant, some people assume that people with celiac disease don't eat gluten just for better health and not because gluten triggers an autoimmune response. In this case, the gravity of the disease isn't taken seriously, and they may get served foods containing gluten anyway.

QuestionText.Text: Why does the text mention grains?

AnswerSentence.Text: They contain a substance that is dangerous to some.
They cause some people to gain a lot of weight.
They are part of a healthy diet.
They can be modified to be gluten-free.

QuestionText.Text: How does the gluten-free movement affect people with celiac disease?

AnswerSentence.Text: It is both helpful and harmful to patients.
It has made some food options too expensive.
It causes people to worry too much about gluten.
It has introduced better treatments for patients.

QuestionText.Text: In the last sentence, what does the word "gravity" mean?

Material.Text: "Reduce, reuse, recycle" is a mantra we have been hearing for some time now. Significant effort has been put into many citywide recycling efforts, but what about the other Rs in the slogan? Recycling is laudable, but how can we reduce our waste and reuse more things? One consideration to make in order to reduce more is to decrease our overall consumption. Creating meal plans for the week, looking for products with less packaging, and using energy-efficient light bulbs are just a few ways to minimize overall consumption and therefore waste. And as for reusing, people should consider donating or reselling usable clothing or objects and buying items secondhand. "Repurposing" is also becoming increasingly popular, taking things that would normally become trash and transforming them into something brand new.

QuestionText.Text: What is the author's opinion about recycling?

AnswerSentence.Text: It is helpful but not sufficient to reduce waste.
It hasn't been implemented properly in cities.
It isn't as important as decreasing consumption.
It has encouraged people to reduce and reuse.

QuestionText.Text: Why does the author mention meal plans?

AnswerSentence.Text: to suggest ways to avoid buying too much
to suggest ways to stop overeating
to suggest ways to reuse food packaging
to suggest ways to save energy when cooking

QuestionText.Text: What might be a good example of repurposing?

AnswerSentence.Text: using an old pair of jeans to make a purse
installing a shower that saves on water
buying a set of used dishes instead of new ones
donating lightly used items to charity

Material.Text:
Personnel Procedures Guidelines

Section 4.1

Open and honest dialogue is encouraged throughout the workplace. Nevertheless, interpersonal conflicts between coworkers will occasionally arise. Employees in such situations are encouraged to first attempt to discuss and resolve workplace conflicts face-to-face with their colleagues through calm discussion. If conflict remains, the involved parties should seek the help of a neutral third party in a position of relative authority, such as one of the employees supervisors or a manager. If the dispute continues after third-party mediation, employees should contact Human Resources to file a grievance. Human Resources will then launch an investigation into the matter.

Note: Human Resources offers monthly seminars on topics related to preventing workplace conflict and the development of effective communication strategies. The schedule is posted monthly on the Human Resources page of the company website.

QuestionText.Text: What topic does this text mainly discuss?

AnswerSentence.Text: relationships between senior and junior staff

QuestionText.Text: According to the author, when should someone contact Human Resources?
What is the purpose of the note at the end of the text?

AnswerSentence.Text: to announce a change of schedule

Material.Text: The term "open-source software" refers to software code that is available for programmers to view, use, and develop as they want. One of the major benefits of open-source software is that developers don't have to create from scratch, and they can work collaboratively with other programmers without worrying about intellectual property. Open-source projects are often (but not always) free, and they are usually more secure than their closed-source counterparts. On the down side, however, because it is open, it is possible for someone to use your code to create a competing product. Also, because these products are often made by and for developers, the user interface is not always easy to use. For many, though, the pros outweigh the cons, and open-source software remains a staple of the programming community.

QuestionText.Text: In this text, what does "closed-source software" probably refer to?

AnswerSentence.Text: software that is often available without purchase
software that is easy for non-programmers to use
software that is used to teach programmers how to code
software that is only available to professionals

QuestionText.Text: Which of these is one of the negatives of open-source software?

AnswerSentence.Text: It can be difficult to operate.
